description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays Update I am now building these and selling these on my Etsy! So if you don't have a printer yet, I will be happy to print you one! Check it out at https://www.etsy.com/listing/109657227/ Update 2: I've been making a lot of little changes that I realize I never uploaded here. So now I have. V3.1 for your consuming pleasure. All pieces are now the latest version. If you want the old version, I don't know why, you can still get the plate. Featuring improved couplers for easier assembly and disassembly, better proportions and appearance, and a more printable design. Carry your chess set to your next game in the coolest way possible. This thing was made largely in tinkercad and can be edited online at https://tinkercad.com/things/9EMMYZIfQwy

Assemble by :
  • Forming the head and body by sliding the queen's tab into the middle of the king and sliding down.
  • Form shoulders by sliding in the two flat bottomed pawns into the body.
  • Form feet and legs by mating two of the pawns base-to-base and attaching the knights to one end. Then join the legs to the body at the hips.
  • Form the arms by mating one pawn base-to-base with the rook, and the bishop to the pawn. (Detail lovers will make sure the fingers are in the right place.) Then snap the rook into the shoulder pawn.
    • Disassemble by reversing the steps to play chess.

title: SNES Raspberry Pi 3 with functional switches, LED, and USB ports
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is my case for a Raspberry Pi 3, designed like a mini SNES and with functional front USB ports, power/reset switches, front LED, and fan.

After the NES Classic was released last year, I've been wanting to make my own SNES mini console with a Raspberry Pi 3. This case used carjo3000's Pi Zero case as a starting point, and I made several modifications to make it work with the Pi 3. The case has many small details that match the specs of an original SNES, and it's about 50% smaller than an SNES case.

I have plans to add a functioning lid that is compatible with Steven Chan's mini SNES cart, so more files will be added. However, if you don't care about the lid then all the files listed below are complete and sufficient for making your own mini SNES.

Please see the parts list and guide below to make your own mini SNES!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

25%

Notes:

See guide for details on printing.

Parts List

1 x Raspberry Pi 3

1 x SD card

1 x 2.5 Amp micro USB power supply

1 x HDMI cable

1 x Tactile Switch
https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/te-connectivity-alcoswitch-switches/1825027-5/450-1662-ND/529484

1 x SPDT Switch
https://www.digikey.com/products/en/switches/slide-switches/213?k=EG1903-ND

2 x USB Female Ports
https://www.digikey.com/products/en?keywords=UE27AC54100-ND

1 x Custom USB extender board
https://www.oshpark.com/shared_projects/FAyLBjUv

1 x Fan
https://www.amazon.com/Gdstime-25mm-Small-Brushless-Cooling/dp/B00MWJSNSS/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&qid=1470945192&sr=8-2&keywords=25mm+5v+fan&linkCode=sl1&tag=daftmike-20&linkId=9ed08e9936c305cacaff2553c65b9c56

1 x MOSFET
http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/ON-Semiconductor/NDD02N40-1G/?qs=%2fha2pyFadujCfrM0U5vo5UW1IB2%252bXxCUrqF9pjELuHWPdKaxIT5kqg%3d%3d

1 x 10 kOhm Resistor
http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Vishay-Dale/CCF0710K0GKE36/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMsPqMdJzcrNwnPpI93fAKplguGM0C8rEjs%3d

1 x Red 3.0 mm LED with 270 Ohm resistor
(available at microcenter or any online electronics store)

GPIO Jumper Cables
(available at microcenter or any online electronics store)

1 x Perfboard
http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Adafruit/2670/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMufdu5QM0tCwbk7gse1KwnzzpqXpp259ss%3d

6 x screws (4 x 3/8"). Shorter screws should also work, but this was what I used in the initial build.

1 x Spring from a "clicky" pen. I tried out a few and I think that most springs from these pens should work fine.

Other smaller accessories like cables, heat shrink wrap, solder, wire stripper, hot glue gun, and a helping hands. I used an old USB cable for most of my wire. Some soldering skills are required here, so purchase some cheap perf board, find a good youtube soldering tutorial, and practice if you're new to soldering.

---------------------------------Build Guide----------------------------------------------------------------

3D Print Your SNES Case!

I have a Monoprice Maker select, and I used the following filaments for printing the case:

-Segaden Gray 1.75mm PLA - this stuff is a perfect color match for the SNES. No painting required!
https://www.amazon.com/SEGADEN-Printer-Filament-Spool-OPR3200GY/dp/B01M4OLJEB

-Inland Silver 1.75mm PLA for the eject button
Available on Amazon or Microcenter. A solid color match for the eject button

-Inland Purple 1.75mm PLA for the Power/Reset buttons and Keys.
Available on Amazon or Microcenter. A decent color match to the buttons, but I'm still searching for a better match.

I printed everything with 200 C for the extruder and 60 C for heating the bed. In Cura, I used the "Supports Everywhere" option and then removed the supports with a pair of pliers and a razor blade afterwards.

The top case, power, and reset buttons should be printed facing up (like how you see it in the thingiverse diagram). This will give you a smoother, more professional look to these parts once the print is complete.

EDIT 9/20/2017: I made some minor changes to the design and uploaded a new fan mount that slides into a slot on the top of the SNES case. The older files that were once posted here will still work, but the new design is easier to set up and provides better airflow than the original design.

I also made a version of the bottom half of the case that has an SD card slot. If you want to have access to the SD card, then print this version instead!

Solder the USB Extender and female USB cables.

Solder together the USB extender PCB (thanks Dustin Westaby) to the two female USB ports, using about 6 inches of USB cable.

On the USB extender, the through holes labeled M (M1, M2) use a white cable, whereas the holes labeled P (P1, P2) will use a green cable. The 5V (Red) and Ground (Black) cables for both USB ports were twisted together and soldered to the 5V and G through holes on the USB extender, respectively.

See image below for the wiring of the USB female ports. Going from left to right, Ground is a black cable, D+ is a green cable, D- is a white cable, and 5V is a red cable. M1 and P1 should go to one USB port, whereas M2 and P2 should go to the second port. I used heat shrink wrap to protect the solder points on the female USB cables, and to prevent any accidental soldering between the pins.

Connect USB extender, Pi3, and USB ports to the case

I inserted the USB extender into the bottom two ports of the Pi 3, and I also flashed an image of retropie to the SD card. Make sure that you connect your Retropie image to the internet. The SD card will no longer be accessible once the build is finished if you use the original bottom.stl file, but it's still accessible with the SD card slot variant.

The case has a cutout for the USB extender and SD card, so carefully angle the Pi in so that it sits as depicted in the photo. The two female USB ports should slide right into their slots, and I use a bit of hot glue on the tops and sides of the ports to lock everything in. Before gluing, make sure that you test both ports with a game pad or a keyboard to make sure that they are working properly.

Wire the Power and Reset Cables

Next, I put together the cables for the power and reset buttons. I needed about 8 inches of cable, and unfortunately the GPIO jumper cables that I purchased were just a little too short. To solve this problem, I soldered on some extra wire from the USB cable that I took apart, and then I used heat shrink wrap to protect the soldering site. Ideally, you can skip this step if you find some longer cables than I did :-)

Once you have cables that are the proper length, you can solder them to the switches as seen above.

Install the Power Switch

The SDPT switch fits into a notch on top of the case, and then it can be secured in place when you insert the 3D printed Power switch. The GPIO cables need to be lined up as seen in the photo, with the unused pin facing the front of the SNES case. From there, use a small amount of hot glue to secure the SPDT switch. Be careful when applying the glue so that it doesn't stick to the power switch.

Secure the Power Switch in place

Once the glue has dried, secure everything in place with the power switch key. Use one of the #4 screws to lock everything in place, ensuring that the SPDT switch is still connected to the 3D printed power switch.

You can't tighten the power key on too tightly, otherwise the power switch won't move. Loosen it just enough so that the power switch moves smoothly. It's also important to have all the scaffolding removed from the print of the SNES case top, and you may want to sand it a little before adding the power key.

Set Up the Reset Switch

Use the spring from the "clicky" pen and insert it in the reset button shaft, along with the reset button as seen in the photo.

Secure the Reset Button

Use a #4 screw to lock in the reset button. As before, you can't tighten the reset key on too tightly, otherwise the switch won't move. Loosen it just enough so that the reset switch moves smoothly. It's also important to have all the scaffolding removed from the print of the SNES case top, and you may want to sand it a little before adding the power key.

When you're finished it should have a nice springy action just like the original SNES reset switch.

Glue on the Reset Switch

Position the reset switch in the same location as seen in the photo, and very carefully add some hot glue to the back and to the side of the switch.

You have to be very careful here - too much glue can reach the front of the switch and prevent it from working, or you can accidentally glue the reset key to the top of the SNES case. It may be helpful to remove the reset key during this step - it will give you a little more room to work.

Once you're finished, the arm on the reset key should consistently hit the switch, and you'll hear the click of the tactile switch every time you push the reset button.

Connect the Switches to the Pi

Time to connect the two halves of the case together! Plug the power switch GPIO pins into pins 5 & 6. Using the photo, the red cable connects to pin 5 and the black cable connects to pin 6.

For the reset button, the green cable connects to pin 3 and the white cable connects to pin 39.

For reference, the GPIO Pin layout on the Pi 3 can be found here:
http://blog.mcmelectronics.com/post/Raspberry-Pi-3-GPIO-Pin-Layout#.WafoKFGQyM8

To make the buttons functional, we need to add some python scripts and edit /etc/rc.local so that they are loaded at startup.

To do this, first download and extract the python scripts folder that I made (thanks Evan Wright for putting these scripts together!):
https://www.dropbox.com/s/n84igea5zksfr2c/scripts.rar?dl=0

From there, use Filezilla or WinSCP to connect to your Pi3. Transfer the scripts folder into the /home/pi/RetroPie/BIOS folder. There are numerous tutorials on youtube for using Filezilla to connect to your Pi3, if needed.

Next, connect a keyboard to your Pi3 and exit EmulationStation. Type:

sudo nano /etc/rc.local

A text editor will pop up. Type the following three lines of code before the line that says "exit 0":

sudo python /home/pi/RetroPie/BIOS/scripts/shutdown.py &
sudo python /home/pi/RetroPie/BIOS/scripts/reboot.py &
sudo python /home/pi/RetroPie/BIOS/scripts/fan_1.py &

Hit CTRL and X to exit, type Y to save, and enter to overwrite the original rc.local. Now type sudo reboot and your Pi 3 will restart. Test out the functionality of your buttons, and everything should work!

After testing, use the remaining #4 screws to secure the Pi to the case. You don't have to go all the way down with the screws or you may go through the bottom of the case! I went down about halfway with the screws and they mainly hold the pi in place when the HDMI or power cable is inserted.

Set up the power LED

Here, we need to solder the 270 Ohm resistor to the positive side of the LED (the positive side on the LED is longer than ground). Next, you will need to solder on two GPIO jumper cables so that the cable length is approximately 6 - 7 inches. As before, my cables were a little short, so I lengthened them by adding some wire from the USB cable that I tore apart. I used heat shrink wrap to cover the 270 Ohm resistor and all the soldering points (in green in the photo).

Lastly, I took a larger diameter heat shrink wrap to cover the entire LED. Make sure that it's black, otherwise light will escape out and make the corner of your SNES console glow red :-)

Finishing up the LED

Use a scissor to cut the front of the heat shrink wrap so that only the tip of the LED is visible. This will allow light to escape from only the front of the LED.

Mounting the LED

The LED will fit snugly in the mounting bracket as seen in the photo. The positive end connects to pin 8, and ground connects to pin 9. Here's the Pi 3 GPIO layout image again:

http://blog.mcmelectronics.com/post/Raspberry-Pi-3-GPIO-Pin-Layout#.WafoKFGQyM8

To activate the LED at startup, we need to edit the boot process so that the serial port is enabled.

Turn on your Pi 3, connect it to a keyboard, and exit EmulationStation. Next type:

sudo nano /boot/config.txt

Go to the end of the text and enter the following line to enable the serial port:

enable_uart=1

As before, type CTRL and X to exit, type Y to save, and type enter to overwrite the config.txt file. Turn on your Pi 3, and now the LED should turn on at startup!

Setting up the fan

The final step is to set up and mount the fan. Cut a small piece of perfboard (5 x 3 holes should work) and solder the MOSFET in the center as seen in the first pic. Next, solder the 10 kOhm resistor on the row beneath the MOSFET (seen in both pics).

After shortening the legs on the MOSFET and the resistors, I then used some solder to connect each leg of the resistor to the closest leg of the MOSFET (seen in the second pic). The legs are all close together, so be careful and make sure the the middle leg on the MOSFET is not accidentally soldered to the left or right legs.

Next, I took two short (2 inch) GPIO jumper cables and soldered them to the left and right sides as seen in the second photo. For the middle MOSFET leg, I clipped the ground wire off the fan, and then soldered it to the middle leg. As before, be careful and make sure that all 3 MOSFET legs are isolated from each other.

Lastly, on the power cable for the fan (red cable), I clipped off 1/2 of the connector so that only the red line remained (see top photo)

Mounting the Fan

I used a small amount of hot glue to attach the fan circuit to the bottom of the case, with the MOSFET facing up. As you can see in the photo, the GPIO to the right of the MOSFET is plugged into pin 12(GPIO 18), and the GPIO to the left of the MOSFET is connected to pin 14 (GND). I plugged the 5V for the fan in GPIO pin 2.

Attach the fan to the fan mount, and place the nuts on the front of the fan (the side that has the logo). This will allow the fan mount to easily slide into the notches on the top of the SNES. In this photo, I set it up the wrong way with the nuts on the fan mount and it was too tight of a fit. Once it's mounted, add some hot glue to lock the fan in place.

The code for the fan was already added in a previous step, so the fan should kick in whenever the pi temp reaches 60 degrees Celsius.

Snap the case closed and test it out!

The case will snap together after all the components have been installed. Give everything a final test, and you're done!

I am working on some other case mods, and I will add these parts and update the guide accordingly. Current plans are to make a functional lid so that you can insert a mini cartridge (seen in the photo, designed by Steven Chan).

Special thanks again to Carjo3000, Dustin Westaby, and Evan Wright for their contributions and assistance. Let me know what you think in the comments below!

title: Prusa MK2S feet (for sorbothane dampeners)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I remixed these feet to better suit my needs. In my case for 30mm half-sphere sorbothane dampeners.

But since I was fiddling with them anyway, I also added 40mm and 50mm versions.

-The main feet have slots for a zip-tie, so that it can be attached to the printer without tape/glue.

-The frame feet was just slightly modified to make them clip on to the frame itself. Just enough so that they don't fall off when lifting the printer.

Prusa

i3 MK2S

No

Supports:

No

0.2

20-30%

Printed with PETG.

Main feet at 20% infill, and frame feet at 30% (to make the clips stronger)

Awesome use of the hemisphere dampers!
I work on Sorbothane projects with Isolate It! and we really appreciate you sharing your work.

comments.text: Thanks Porda, that is very interesting!  I would have guessed the bigger the pad the better it would absorb.  It also seems like the hemisphere pads would be more bouncy than the flat ones.   I would be curious to read about the science behind Sorbothane.
comments.author: Porda

comments.text: Hi Bmeist,
comments.author: Bmeist

comments.text: Thanks Porda!  I just ordered the 3/4" inch pack.  I currently have a big block of 2.5 inch rigid packing foam under the whole printer, which works pretty well, but I'm hoping this will reduce the vibrations even more and look much nicer.
comments.author: Porda

comments.text:
Hi. Glad you like them. I haven't noticed any improvement in print quality, but they of course help a lot with absorbing vibrations/resonance.
Also, using the two extra frame feet makes the printer much more stable than just using the four main feet dampeners. Though, naturally it's not as solid as using no dampening feet at all.
Sorbothane is kinda squishy after all.

description.text:
I wasn't a fan of the short, squatty, ugly stock drip tip for my Ammit. So, I made a new one. It measures 15mm tall(5mm insert, 10mm protruding). The insert portion is 12.6mm in diameter with a slight chamfer to aid in insertion. I implemented twist fins which act as an anti-spitback mechanism as well as vapor vortex. Supposedly, this should fit the Goon, Kylin, and other 810 tip tanks, but I haven't tested those as I don't have them.

I've included the Autodesk Fusion 360 file if you need to modify it to fit. Or you could just scale it up/down as needed.

I printed mine in PLA and haven't had any issues with heat deforming or burning/melting. After all, it is quite a ways away from the coils.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 micron - 250 micron

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Should not need supports as the twist fins aren't massively twisted. 90° twist over 14mm height.

Clean-up

You might need to take some small strips of fine sandpaper and run a few passes through each twist slot to remove hangers and blobs. This is entirely dependent on your printer and print settings.

Other ideas - use an epoxy resin clear coat like XTC 3D on outside to make for a better mouth feel. Personally, I don't mind it being textured, so I left mine untreated.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is the hexapod i'm designing. It is a still ongoing process. All the parts for legs and body are printable on any reprap machine as long as it's build surface is at least 200x200mm. It is designed for MG996R servo's, but other types will fit too. As long as they're futaba compatible (just measure the servo's before buying. It has 4DOF (degrees of freedom) per leg. This means you'll need at least 24 servo's for the legs only. The model is updated right now and as soon as it's done i'll post the files. The zipfile contains a sample hexapod code. It can be used as an example depending on what hardware you're using. There is lots of info about software and electronics for the hexapod on http://lynxmotion.com

Finally i could make my printer work. It took some work.
Some more pictures are added from my first part of the hex (tarsus). I'll have to update this part and print it again. Once all parts are tested and printed, the stl's will be on here.

This is a modified version of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2486307. I wanted to give it a closed top and found this teardrop shape the best option. I didn't post DoubleTwistLamp 2 because it had a different shape that just wasn't as nice as this one.

Like DoubleTwistLamp1 this lamp is designed for an LED "puck" light. Battery operated lights are about $4 each; simply do a web search for "puck light". This blog page tells where you can get wall powered lights that work very well: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/wall-powered-led-lights/.

This print took 12 hours 33 minutes at a print speed of 100 mm.sec and layer height of 0.205 mm. It uses the same basic design as https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2484050 so it may be that you have to use the Slic3r slicer to slice it. For details why this is the case see that page or, for more information, this one: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/do-the-twist/.

This is not my design, but since the original creator said we can share, and I couldn't find it on this site - here it is. It prints as a whole unit, not in parts, and amazingly it works straight off the printing bed!

I printed mine on the Flashforge Fidner at 0.08 layer thickness, just to push the printer to see what sort of quality I can get, and it works perfect! Design can be scaled up and down easily, although if you print too small, some parts might fuse.

There's no need for supports or rafts but I did print it with a brim, and I'd recommend using it. Enjoy!

My attempt at organizing the resource and player pieces for Catan Junior.

When everything is printed, it consists of 6 trays holding all the resource and player pieces. This design replaces the default box inlay.

Print the following:
1 x CatanJuniorResource - Tray with 3 slots for resources
1 x CatanJuniorResource2 - Tray with space for 2 resources and the Coco cards, dice and Ghost Pirate piece
4 x CatanJuniorPlayerTray2 - One player tray for each player's pieces

You might need to rotate the models to be flat on the printer bed.

Gopro 360 5 camera waterproof rig. Print and snap cameras into place. Recommend at least 30% infill. Was printed on a replicator 2. One 1/4 nut needed for tripod mounting. This rig provides excellent overlap side to side and video can be shot in most modes including 16:9. Their are blind spots top and bottom viewing in 360. I have yet to design top camera to create near 360 video.

remixed_from.title: Cable Chain Remix for Pro Operation

title: Cable Chain Remix for Pro Operation Remix

description.text:
This is a small change to the "Cable Chain Remix for Pro Operation" model. The original ones had 5mm holes, which were too tight to freely spin an M5 bolt, which means you can't tighten them properly against your square or T-nuts. They also were solid all the way through, and thus required a weird size M5 I couldn't find. 25mm was too short, 30 was too long, and the stores around me don't carry intermediate sizes.

I just modified the original models expanding the bolt hole to 5.5mm, and added a 10.25mm inset hole 15.5mm into them, so there's a 4.5mm bit of plastic for the bolt to hold into, but the 10mm bolts that are used for everything else on D-Bot and derived printers fit with these. Otherwise they're identical.

comments.text: I wish I had seen this sooner. I ended up trimming a longer bolt to get it to fit. Unfortunately, the tip of the bolt ended up getting stuck in my bolt shear. Doh!

title: Printer Bed Scraper with Replaceable Printed Blades
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spatula for removing objects from the print bed, with easily replaceable printable blades. When one side of the blade gets worn out, just turn the other side. And the best thing is that it won't damage your print bed!

Blades come in 4 types: Soft - for general use, Hard - for removing stubborn objects, Combo having one soft and one hard side, and finally Extra-Hard or "XHard".

For better performance, make sure that the blade label is turned downwards.

Blades can be printed in either material. It is advisable to use a blade of the same material as the object that is being removed.

UPDATE 2018-02-11
  • Added Extra-Hard (XHard) blades
  • Removed GCODE files for blades
UPDATE 2017-09-26
  • NEW Scraper Handle v2 has closed sides, keeping the blade firmly in place and preventing it from sliding out sideways. It also does not require supports anymore, but you should enable bridging parameters detection.
  • If a single-piece print does not work for you, a split v2 version is also included.
  • Important: In order to ensure a proper slit size, you should first calibrate the extrusion using this model: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2372705
UPDATE 2017-09-04
  • Some users have experienced troubles removing supports from the slit of the Printer Bed Handle, so I included a 2-part split version. Glue after printing.
  • Fixed a minor error in STL file. Does not affect already enclosed GCODE files.
Feel free to tip me if you like this! :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Resolution:

0.15, 0.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:
Handle v2
  • Layer height: 0.20 mm
  • Infill: 20%
  • Supports: No
  • Detect bridging perimeters: Yes
  • support_material_contact_distance = 0.2 (detachable)
  • perimeters = 3
  • dont_support_bridges = 1
  • first_layer_height = 0.2
Handle (old)
  • Layer height: 0.20 mm
  • Infill: 20%
  • Supports: Yes
  • support_material_contact_distance = 0.2 (detachable)
  • perimeters = 3

  • first_layer_height = 0.2
Blade
  • Layer height: 0.15 mm
  • Supports: No
  • perimeters = 3
  • first_layer_height = 0.2
GCODE Files

The gcode files are sliced with Slic3r using standard ABS and PLA settings for Prusa Mk2.

Removing Supports From the Handle

Be careful to remove all supports from the handle slit, before inserting a blade. The enclosed GFILES are set with 0.2 mm contact-distance, which makes the supports easier to remove.

If you have troubles removing the supports from the slit, then use the included Printer_Bed_Handle_Split.stl file to slice and print using your proven printing preferences.

description.header: Removing an Object From the Print Bed
description.text:
• Wait for the heat bed to cool down! Pulling an object while the bed is still hot may damage the PEI sheet and cause it to lift, or even tear off! A hot bed will also soften the blade.
  • Try inserting the scraper underneath one of angles and work your way along the perimeter.
  • Try wiggling the object or tapping it slightly, to ease the bond with the bed.
  • Spray one angle using a compressed air can, holding it upside-down. This will cause the object and the bed to instantly freeze, relieving the bond at that point. Now starting from there, use the scraper/spatula to release the rest of the object.
  • You can also pour some IPA (isopropyl alcohol) near the object and let it sit there for a few minutes, working its way underneath the object. Use the scraper to release the object.
    CAUTION: Pouring IPA on an object, (especially when still hot) leaves some residuum on a print bed, that will prevent filament in further prints from properly sticking to it. Therefore, after removing the object you must thoroughly wipe the bed using white paper tissues and clean IPA.
Removing PETG Objects

PETG is notorious for being difficult to remove from a PEI bed. The following tips should make your life a bit easier regarding that problem.

  1. Before printing a PETG object, you can optionally spray the PEI bed with Windex or a similar glass cleaning spray, and let it evaporate. It will leave a thin silicone layer that prevents the material from sticking too firmly to the bed.
  2. After the printing, heat the bed again (if already cooled down).
  3. Turn the heating off.
  4. Start removing the object as described above while the bed is cooling, but before it gets back below 40°C.

This works because the object is cooling at a different rate than the PEI bed, so you get some thermal advantage.

You can also help yourself by pouring some IPA at the object's perimeters, as described above.

There are three blade versions according to the hardness:

  • Soft, having two soft sides, for general use;
  • Hard, having two hard sides, for removing stubborn objects;
  • Combo, having one soft, and one hard side.

There are three blade versions according to their label:

  • Blade with "PLA" label printed on the bottom;
  • Blade with "ABS" label printed on the bottom;
  • Blade with no label.

The enclosed GCODE files have also 1 piece, and 8 pieces variations of all the above options.

title: Ryobi TS1352 Throat Plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As the throat plates for my Ryobi TS1352 Compound Miter Saw are discontinued, I created this design as a replacement.

This is a drop-in replacement, and can be printed in ABS or PLA. Just be aware that PLA may not stand up to tons of direct sunlight in the heat.

Update: I added a Zero Clearance version, which is basically the same with no slot cut. The downside is that you may want to print it with 100% (or nearly 100%) infill, as you'll be using your saw to cut the slot you need. I also recommend using ABS for the Zero Clearance version if you can, as it'll cause less wear on your blade than PLA.

title: Prusa i3 MK2S + Raspberry Pi 3 Model B + 3.5" Adafruit PiTFT Plus Display Mount

description.text:
Based on my specific requirements, I was looking for a RPi3 case that holds the 3.5" Adafruit PiTFT screen and could be easily mounted on the printer's frame, so I modified bolsoncerrado's version and added:

  • Sliding dovetails for easy mountin/unmount on the printers frame
  • Moved 2mm the screen frame to the right for improved fitting
  • Moved 1.7mm the audio jack hole up for improved fitting

In addition, I chose this version over others because it allowed me to take out the original RPi camera cable from either side of the case. As you can see, the cable is coming out from the right side since the camera is going to be on the right side of the heatbed.

author: cnPv_official

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b2rlhtFEO9G

I got tired of always having to reach around the printer to power it off then back on after a print finished in order to set the temps. so the hot ends would heat back up for the next print. Now I have a switch in easy reach

This was designed for a "Carlingswitch LRA911-RS-B/120N Lighted Rocker Switch" I found for $0.99 including shipping on ebay. I don't want it to light up so I wired it up for just the switch without the light.

This is also setup to work with the Bibo2 feet I made https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415596

Since the switch has no markings to show on from off I used a permanent marker to make a black line on the switches "ON" side.

I did have to replace the blade connector on the wire going to the power supply since the one that was on the wire was for a smaller blade (the one on the stock main power switch) than what's on the switch and therefore wouldn't fit. The old connector literally fell off in my hand anyway so it had to be replaced.

title: xxs delta
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After building some large delta's it's time to make things smaller

I remixed some parts from this nice design, the Sculptr Delta MK1 by 3dprintingtips (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444028).

Fully printable on a 22mm bed.
Has no heated bed and runs on a MKS MINI board.
The print bed is a makeup mirror with a 8cm diameter (Don't tell my wife).
Printing size approx 80mm in diameter and 126mm z highed

------------------------------------------------------UPDATE-------------------------------------------------
I uploaded a different version of the effector V2 the original uploaded file does not work properly.
Ino has also been uploaded. (arduino 1.6.1)

Some specs

Diagonal rod lenght 82// mm
Smooth rod offset 83.0// mm
Effector offset 22.0/ mm (uploaded config_h state's 20, please change)
Carriage offset 20.0 // mm
Maximal print high is aproxaly 126.0//mm
Pully teeth for the beld is 16 GT2
Timing belt GT2
Extruder is a mk8 full metal
Stepper motor 42mmx42mm

Rod ends are traxxas. The rods themself are made of 4mm threaded bar.

Bearings used for the carriage:
Bearing type: LM8UU
Length: 24 mm
Inner diameter: 8 mm
Outer diameter: 15 mm

Clips for the LM8UU bearings
Diameter: 15 mm
Material: Steel
Thick: 1 mm

Vertical rods for the LM8UU bearings are in this build 8mm steel rods and 300mm in length. So i could make 3 out of a 1000mm rod. Yep i'm Dutch :)
The aluminium stabilizer rods are 330mm of length.

Hotend is a stock E3D v6 lite
Current setup has no second fan to cool the layer (yet).
I uploaded the second fan holder. This one can be used as a add on for the fan duct that's included by the E3D v6 lite. The layer cooling fan is controlled by the MKS MINI. So you have to make a direct 12v connection for the hot end. This ensures that you always have this fan running.

Motherboard a MKS mini V1.2, this one has no option for a heated bed.
If you want this option, you have to add a mos module.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No support or rafts required.

The stepper motor has m3 threaded rod pre inserted for fasten them onto the base. It's easier to do it like this rather than using m3 bolts.

First place the gt2 belt gear onto the stepper shaft. Before placing the stepper motor.

The carriage has LM8UU linear bearings which are hold into place with LM8UU bearing clips.

The carriage glides on 8mm steel rods. The outer rod is made of aluminium and is hollow. Therefore you can guide the endstop wiring through them.
The rod ends are made from traxxas rod ends and m4 threaded rod.

title: NES-101 Top Loader Multi-out panel replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement AV/Power panel for an NES-101 that includes a proprietary Nintendo Multi-out port instead of the regular holes for RF out & channel select. This isn't quite perfect yet. I'm still working on it & will likely be uploading newer versions in the future. If you have suggestions/comments, please let me know!

I haven't uploaded my PCB design files yet. When I do, I'll add a link in here. I decided to move the screw hole off to one side so that the board can't be inserted upside-down so using the db electronics PCB (http://db-electronics.ca/wiki/wikis/projects/snes-av-multi-out/#The_PCB) won't work with this.

You will need to replace the power connector since it is integrated into the original back panel. You can use something like this as a replacement: https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/cui-inc/PJ-102BH/CP-102BH-ND/408449

This model is based on the panel from an AV Famicom & the connector dimensions from the db electronics SNES multi-out connector that can be found here: http://db-electronics.ca/wiki/wikis/projects/snes-av-multi-out/

title: Elder Wand with Runes in 3 printable parts 15 inch

description.text:
I really wanted to print this Elder Wand design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2109859 at the "official" 15 inch length (see http://harrypotter.wikia.com/wiki/Elder_Wand). However 15 inch is far too big for my printer so I split it into 3 printable parts.

Printing went perfect, now have to finish it (glue, sand and paint). -> Update: done...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20% Rectilinear

Notes:

My Anet A8 printer knocked my first attempt over at approx 10cm height resulting in spaghetti. So I went with a 20mm brim, 7 layer raft and approx. 45 layers of support from the build plate to lock it down tight (see pictures). Had no trouble after that.

This is my first attempt at splitting an existing object. I used OpenSCAD to generate the individual parts and added rod/sockets to the parts for easy gluing. The OpenSCAD script is included as you might find it useful for splitting other objects.

Because of the complexity of the source file, the render takes quite some time in OpenSCAD, so be patient.

title: Customizable (Dremel) Disc Shape Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this as a simple helper for my Dremel drill press stand, to help form discs from a square stock.

Take the stock you want to make a disc out of and and mark the center and the radius. Drill a hole in the center and attach it to the plug. I am using the drill I used for drilling the hole here, but you can use anything that fits both holes.

Adjust your rotary tool so that it just barely touches the corners. Rotate your material, move the rotary toll further to the material. Repeat this step until you have the radius of your choice, you might need to push the rotary tool a little bit into the material once it gets round, but does not yet have the reached the proper diameter.

The customizer allows you to customize the size of the inner hole, diameter of the plug and the support on top and the height of both.

The attached STL is an export of the default configuration and should allow a 2mm Drill to fit in the center.

This is basically a remix and simplification of one of my earlier designs, although the earlier one also allows for cutting holes, which this does not.

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula

No

Supports:

No

0.2

20%

Prints in less than 10 minutes!

Printed with my TEVO Tarantula 3D printer - great printer for a really low price!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Edit: I made a Version 2 of the spraycan handle/trigger. I was not thinking of revising it when I put it up, so it's a bit of an after thought.

Someone was wanting a printable handle/trigger for spraycans on a facebook group. I only noticed one of these on thingiverse. I decided to give it a try and this is what I came up with. It prints in one piece and doesn't need support. It pressfits onto the spray cans.
The pros to it are that it's one piece with no hardware or supports needed. The cons are that not a machines handle tolerances the same, so it may not for some. This is why I am including a small test part as well. Print it before printing the full handle. If it fits you have a good chance of the full thing fitting. If it fails than you did not waste as much time or filament printing the full handle Other problems could simply include the joint fusing together. You can see a full video of it here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IxVCsVSmEsw

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I only used 10% infill on this with 3 outer shells or perimeters. The handle has a built in gap to reduce filament cost.
I have a more detailed video linked above.

I was not expecting to refine this at all. This was partly done based on others thoughts and on a personal thing I wanted to change.

The V2 ditches the large curve. This was done to improve the look of it without using supports. I don't care too much on looks for functional prints, but even I will admit that the curve would look a bit better with supports. Instead we go at the exact same angle that the handle runs. The only other difference is the angle of the trigger. I changed the angle to chop off some of the waste plastic that can be seen protruding through the top of the original while in use. These are the only changes I made to the V2.

These are rough measurements

I should of done this earlier, but I am doing it now. Below are the rough height measurements for the tips or nozzles on the spray cans I had on hand.

Red tips 11.08mm in height

White tip 13.80mm in height

comments.text: I have now printed two of these spray can handles and both have broken in the same spot. It seems like the trigger cannot handle very much pressure. Are you using special filament? Or are you printing it on its side? Do you have any suggestions for how I may get a more solid sturdy print.?

title: Subaru Outback (5th gen) smartphone mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was driving around in a rental Malibu, and noticed that it had these two slots in the center console that were obviously made so a phone could slide right into them vertically. Dumbfounded. What a neat feature! I had to have one...

Should fit all 5th Gen Subaru Outbacks that have a center console that looks like mine. The general idea is that you can plug your phone in, and then drop it into the cradle. iPhone 6 plus users should be able to reach their home buttons easily.

Be sure to use a rubber band as shown in the pictures. It seems to do best with a tall elastic as shown, but I'm sure if you double or triple up thinner ones it'll be fine. The plug uses the rubber band both to seal against the opening and to apply pressure to the plastic clip. The plug has a distinct wedge at the base of the plug that grips the seam between the top of the console, and the pocket plastic underneath. Mine has a nice "click" when it slides home.

The cradle is 88mm (X) wide by 17mm (Y) thick by 20mm (Z) deep. My LG V20 in a Speck case is approximately 11mm thick and drops right in with probably too much room to spare in the Y and doesn't touch the center stack or console. But that also means my wife's iPhone 6plus in a wallet case fits just fine too.

With summer heat cycles, I may need to add another clip to the rear of the dock like in the front, but so far it's doing great!

Update Sept 4, 2017: Added a smaller one. The opening on this one is 75mm x 14mm and should accommodate non-phablet style phones. I don't have one to test with, but should work.

Update Sept 19, 2017: Added a 77mm x 14mm variant. Also added step and igs files for the phablet mount.

comments.text:
Fitted the nut for my 300mm, 1mm pitch, single start, Chinese stainless lead screw perfectly (tight fit)
No wobble on the printer initially but the tolerances on the new screw meant that there was severe binding of the Z drive mechanism. Fitting this mod went from the screw having a three point contact to a two point, allowing the motors to run freely. Good job!

title: Kamerahalterung für Foscam C2 an Raise3D Drucker

description.text:
Die Halterung ist für den Raise N1, da dieser oben eine ca. 20mm hohes "Abschlussblech hat (3mm Dicke). Ob das auch beim N2 auch so ist weiß ich nicht. Diese Kante ist bestens dfür geignet, darauf eine Halterung zu stecken. Einfaches Festdrücken reicht völlig.

Die Montage ist sehr einfach und auf den Bildern gut zu erkennen. Die Kamera hat zwei Scheiben, wobei die eine auf der Halterung festgeschraubt ist und dann die Kamera so auf die Scheibe angesetzt wird, dass die beiden an den beiden Platten sichtbaren "Nasen" übereinander liegen. Anschließend muss man die Kamera nur ein wenig drehen, damit sie fest sitzt.

Beim Drucken gib es keine Besonderheiten. Ich habe die Halterung mit PLA gedruckt. Das gebogene Teil muss man nur richtig aufs Druckbett legen, damit kein Support benötigt wird. Die Teile sind etwas dicker als eigentlich nötig. Aber dadurch ist das Ganze wesentlich stabiler und schwingt nicht so.

For those times when you're playing one of those flight simulators that can take ALL THE BUTTONS AND SWITCHES you can throw at it.

This mainly came about because I play simulators in VR wherever possible, and mapping those extra functions that don't fit on the X55 to the keyboard isn't ideal because you can't find the right key without taking the HMD off! This design gives you a total of 19 extra switches/buttons.

I've tried to match things aesthetically to the rest of the X55, so I've used green LEDs and translucent PLA diffusers. The switches are momentary 2-position, again to match the switches on the throttle, with the exception of the hazard switch which is a momentary single.

All the fixings are M3 for simplicity.

Parts I used:
Black PLA
Yellow PLA
Translucent PLA
Green 5V LED strip link
8x momentary 2-position toggle switches link
1x momentary toggle switch with missile cover link
1x DSD 32 button controller link
1x USB panel mount cable link
2x 20mm panel mount push buttons, red (can't find them online, scavenged a bunch of them from a skip a while ago)
20x 20mm M3 bolts
12x 10mm M3 bolts
28x M3 nuts
About 500mm of 10-way ribbon cable, plus a bunch of other wires for connecting up LEDs etc
25x female crimp pins 0.1" link

You will need to print (in black unless otherwise specified):
1x Upper
1x Lower
1x Upper switch mount
2x Upper switch cover
1x Upper buttons
1x Upper hazard sw
1x Upper hazard strips (in yellow)
1x Rear cover
1x Lower switch mount
1x Lower switch cover
8x LED diffuser (in translucent, 100% infill)

At some point I'll draw up a proper build guide, but it's fairly simple.

I opened up the X55 stick base and drilled two holes in both the front and back for the M3 mounting screws, plus a bigger hole (up to 9mm, but mine was 6mm) to pass through the link cable between the upper and lower sections. I used the printed upper and lower to mark where the holes should be.

Once the upper and lower are bolted on and you've passed through your link cable (I used some 10-way ribbon cable I had lying around) pop the base back on to the X55 stick. It's a tight-ish fit, but I've found this makes it very sturdy.

The LED's were the longest part of the build. I first used some super glue, just a dab either side of the LED slots in the switch mounts, to attach them. I then soldered them up in a chain and used some heat shrink to cover them. I used 2 wires of the ribbon cable to run 5V and GND down to the lower section, and also soldered an extra wire to the negative side to allow me to ground the middle contact of the switches.

The switches then went in. They push the LEDs out a bit but the heat shrink prevents any contact and the bend radius is far from damaging. I then connected the other 8 wires in the ribbon cable to the 8 switch positions in the lower section (2 per switch), and chained the GND wire to the middle contacts of each switch.

The upper LED section is much the same, and I used ribbon cable again to make things a bit simpler.

The DSD controller gets bolted to the rear cover (don't forget to use a spacer of some sort), as does the panel mount USB cable.

Connect the 5V headers on the DSD board to the 5V feeds for the LEDs, and then connect up the switches in order. Use the guide

Bolt the rear cover on, connect a USB cable and you should be good to go!

description.text:
A set of metal "base toppers" that can add some steampunky, modern, or scifi flare to an otherwise vanilla 25mm round base. Comes with a Nerdhaus Mini Base for easy assembly in any slicing program; the individual toppers can also be used separately as greebling on a larger structure.

Currently includes seven variations: Three types of diamond tread flooring, three types of stamped metal grating (hex, circular, and "expanded metal"), as well as a somewhat more complex "woven metal" topper.

The woven metal version is unlikely to print out nicely on lower resolution printers (I'm using a .2mm nozzle and it's at the edge of my MakerSelect i3's abilities) but should look fantastic on a high-res resin printer.

Also included is the SCAD file that was used to generate all of the toppers — if you're looking for a quick way to spit out assorted metal flooring textures, this could be your place to look.

comments.text:
I have a pretty loose attitude towards scaling.
I leave it to the folks downloading to decide the scale they want to use.
I mostly just scale my models big. (I usually just make them 120-130 mm tall by default (but not a "rule"))
in the case of these, I would scale them small to keep them consistent with the rockets.
overall I tend to go lots bigger than the scale you work in. (my stuff is usually 120 mm or taller)
this is why often my details get lost when they are scaled small.
that being said, small has some great advantages (speed, material, storage of completed models(I have a real
problem storing the big prints i have in abundance!))

description.text:
This is a robotic lawn mower cutting disc designed for the Liam6 robotic lawn mower, but could be used for any mower with an M8 bolt for the axis.

The ideas behind the design are to:

  1. distribute forces a bit to allow for printing with a lower strength material, like PLA,
  2. allow for the knives (standard robotic lawn mower knives with their M4 screws) to freely rotate around their screws, thereby reducing damage due to mechanical chock,
  3. lower the cutting disc to a level corresponding to a max grass height of approximately 4 cm for the Liam6 design, and,
  4. protect the spinning knives with a cover as in some commercial mowers.

FreeCAD files are included.

Knives, with their screws for free rotation, can, e.g., be found on ebay.

title: Lead Weight Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a from-scratch design, so not really a remix, but is heavily inspired by berkey93's very nice Pulsar Spinner with embedded hex nuts: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2108748

My four year old son can't play with the fidget spinner that he was given because his hands are too small for it to rotate past his palm, so i wanted to make something smaller. Additionally, I have always thought the traditional "tri-spinner" with the four outer bearings was really a waste of bearings, since the outer ones were used for nothing more than rotational mass.

I whipped up this spinner that uses lead weights for rotational mass. It uses a 608 skate bearing for the center axis and uses the simple rectangular lead weights that you can buy at any hobbyshop (or amazon) because I do not have time to melt lead into a custom shape.

The lead weights are smaller than 608 bearings, so I was able to get the overall diameter down to 58mm, which is just small enough to allow my son to play with it. In order to get it down to this size, it uses only 4 lead weights. I also made a 6 and 8 weight version.

The weights are embedded in the spinner, so pause your print just before the ceiling of the weight cavities prints, insert the weights, and resume the print. The ceiling is at z=5.90mm.
I'm not going to go into how to pause at the right point becasue you either already know or you can look it up (M600, Prusa colorprint, etc).

If you want to print center caps for the main bearing, I recommend the same as berkey93: 2ROBOTGUY's very nice twist caps here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802260

Here are some lead weights that will fit: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0015KLJE0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

As always, i have included the native Solidworks files so you can edit to your heart's content

description.text:
Anet A8 Leadscrew drive
At first i need to say thanks to SmallArtFly for making the whole Anet A8 frame in customize able CAD files without him nothing were possible

First Mill Tests in Beech (Hardwood)
https://youtu.be/dqIOYJaO77g

https://youtube.com/watch?v=4-tTspEUVCM

https://youtu.be/NwmaC28zOCE

Anet A8 Mill / Engraving Machine
Hardware Status: Done
Added Anet Frame Parts With Additional I-typ Hold for mill Extension
Added a file with complete machine for help were the parts should be (95% done)
Got Bored today so i made support for second Y Stepper
New Parts Added and Complete machine view updated

Firmware Status: Done
Final solution for Firmware is ESTLCAM it coms with a firmware
for Arduino 2560 and ramps 1.4 and can be used for milling a nice
and simple tool like cura etc can be used as demo but should be buyed
its worth the 49€ the coder should be paid for it its rly a nice software
https://www.estlcam.de/

so "printer" is ready to mill now and in its final size(240x500mm) and stability
travelway is 944mm so it is able to mill the printed parts without any problem
also parts which are bigger then 500mm in once.

will post some more Videos when i start to make the anet parts from alloy

Parts For Anet A8 CNC Mill / Engraving Machine
For Most People it will not be possible to Print the Complete Machine
you need at least a heat bed of 440x220cm to print some parts
for this problem use my Anet A8 parts to double your heat bed as suggestion
Things needed:
4 Leadscrews T2 8x500mm in 2° or more (i use 2°)
4x Nema 17 Stepper Motors (I took 59 Ncm)
4x Bearing 22x8mm
11x Linear Bearing LMUU 8mm
4x Motor - Lead Screw adapter
A lot of m3 Screws in different length from 10mm - 30mm
1x Mill Spine
Old Arduino 1.0 for 3d printing
Ramps 1.4 for milling and ESTLCAM
https://www.estlcam.de/

For Additional X Axis Stabilizing
Steelrods from mill tray are to weak for alloy and needs stabilized
450mm I-Typ Profile
Fotos will get Posted when parts are build next weeks

For extension
1x Leadscrew T2 8x1000mm
2x steelrod 8x960mm
2x screws 8x1000mm
2x I-typ Profiles 1000mm
6x I-Typ Profile 500mm
2x I-Typ Profile 250mm
32x ballbearing 6x3mm for the sleds

Found a solution for Ramps 1.4 Boards with ESTLCAM wich
comes with firmware for this board so i will not search for any
other

Attention!!!!
When u want to print with it with the arduino 1.0, you need to change some things in firmware!!!
the 2° lead screws dont like Accelerations over 2 mm/s and a maximum speed as far as i tested of 10 mm/s.(but can be higher still testing)
else the Motor clutch is releasing and nothing moves (sounds ugly and cant be good for the stepper)
also u need to setup the the steps per mm in firmware for me it was 1600 but depends on your leadscrew and steppers and must be calculated!!!!!
http://www.prusaprinters.org/calculator/#stepspermmlead

Printer:

Anet A8 440x220

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm, 2mm wall top and bottom

Infill:

20%

Notes:

the x holder parts should be printed with infill 100%

still no firmware, need to wait for the ramps 1.4 board, there is still just the anet 1.0 controller in and i dont want to waste my time by trying to getting it to mill with thiis controller. maybe in a week i can post videos when the ramps arrived.
i dont think it will be hard stress the steppers have around 5,9 kg and its a mill its not so fast no hard acceleration like a 3d printer, atm it moves with 10 mm/s acc. with 2 mm/s the lead screws make it slow. there is some yt video from some other guy which did something like this
other small problem i have... i need to learn how to mill ;-)

The issue is not with acceleration, speed, stepper torque but the overall rigidy of the machine verus the stress induced by the milling. Lead screw backlash can lead to trouble too.
I have yet to see such plastic machine mill anything else than depron, balsa, plastic ...

Very slight remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1974412/ to try to add a little strength to it.

This is particularly intended for those, like me, who are still newbies and are printing in PLA only. PLA really doesn't have a lot of strength and where the screw head sits in the tensioner can be ripped open pretty easily. I shored it up a little bit and use a regular M3 30 screw and 2 washers. I think it's added some strength to the tensioner.

Good luck... use at your own risk.

title: DJI Phantom landing gear risers to clear gimbled camera

description.text: This is a set of landing gear risers for a DJI Phantom quad copter to raise it enough to keep a camera and gimble setup from dragging in the dirt. These don't require replaceing or removing any original parts, just push them into place on each corner of the original landing rails and zip tie them in place, slots are provided for the zip ties. I also spread the contact feet out a bit for more stability. I can't say if DJI had more than one mold for their landing gear rails and these are made to fit snug in the rails on my Phantom so print a set and let me know. the extra riser is shorter to clear the compass if still in the original position.

This is a bolt designed to fit into the holes created by removing the rear view mirrors on BMW S1000R motorcycles. I recommend you print with black PLA. 3D printing has the advantage of not rusting, as this is not a structural component. I orginally bought metal bolts but they quickly rusted and gave up on buying metal as I had a 3D printer and black PLA.

I printed with a layer height of .2mm, no supports, 100% infill, 190C hot end, 60C plate. Also, you need to flip the object 180 degrees so the top of the bolt rests on the build plate.

All credit for design goes to https://www.reddit.com/user/BavarianMurderWeapon from the subreddit https://www.reddit.com/r/motorcycles/ he was the one that designed the bolt, I merely printed and tested.

These are a set of wingtip light mounts for a Sonex aircraft. Two variants are included - one for Whelen Orion lights and one for AeroLed Pulsar NXP lights. They have not yet been tested on a flying vehicle, but they should have the correct viewing angles (please verify yourself). These mounts were designed by a novice and are without warranty - you should assume they can fail in many ways.

If you do print these lights please send me a $20 donation via paypal so I can buy beer.

The customizer settings allow for setting the diameter of your handlebars and handlebars, as well as the width of your zip ties.

description.text: Basically this is heavy duty version of the desk grommet (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2411 ) designed to be used in a workbench. The idea was for a way to drop cables through the workbench but at the same time be able to close the hold with something solid enough to stand things on.

This design is untested

title: Butterfly Screen Patch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Found this really nice butterfly print and thought "wow, that would make a really nice patch for a hole in the screen on my porch!" But then the challenge was how to make one that can be installed from one side.

The model has a small catch on the top that the breakaway bar on the side slides into. You'll need to snip off the unused ones, and I find snipping a little taper on one end helps insertion. Don't be too aggressive, there isn't a whole lot of tensile strength in the catch. (I did radius the corners to help distribute the load)

Once the bar is in the catch, you can slide the bar on one side into the hole, slide whole thing to one side until you can position the bar under the screen on the other side, and center. So you are actually looking at the bottom of the model.

Voila!

(for my failed catches, I slipped one of the internal wing parts into a hole, worked nice for small tears)

I'd love to see this printed with a better (or better adjusted) printer.

title: Ghostbusters Neutrino Wand Custom & Fixed Parts

description.text:
Totally remodeled some parts for CountDeM0net's excellent Proton Wand remix.

I found that the front valve and gunbox side didn't fit, due to issues with the origin models (and not having the original STEP/whatever files they came from).

That said, I modeled up total replacements in Sketchup, as the original STL's have horrible mesh issues that were more work to fix than was reasonable.

I've printed and tested these parts - keeping in line with the tight fit philosophy CountDeM0net had on his remix, minor sanding may be required for proper fit.

Updated 9/4/2017 - Added Front Handle Adjuster (Aka the Ear) with properly modeled holes for a standard subminiature pushbutton and 5mm Cliplite lens. Also added the sidecrank mounting pin STL separated from the original source STL's as they were otherwise unavailable.

Huge Update 9/30/2017 - Added a remodeled banjo fitting to properly include the nut detail at one end, as well as a hole for the 1/8 red tubing. Also added an insertable adapter to fit up a GBFans bargraph, as well as an adapter that installs a 10mm LED (GBFans kit style) in the end of the barrel, just peeking out like the original photo flash tubes did. The gunbox front panel was also modified as the Clippard barb hole was too large. It now has a proper sized hole for the #10-32 fitting. It should screw in to the plastic as-printed.

I've also added a printable lens for the bargraph, as when it's printed in clear PLA and flame polished, it has a lenticular-style effect. I also did the same for the vent lens, which mates up with an 8mm LED (ala. GBFans kit).

At the request of my wife, I also made a printable hat light body, as well as a printable hat light body designed to be buried in the model/inserted from behind (the one on top of the gun body). Because the original model's holes are undersize, you will need to drill to fit (11/32 or Letter S). I recommend printing them in translucent PLA and flame polishing. They come out pretty nice.

Updated 11/28/2017 - Added the missing Gunbox Lens (Bargraph Lens).

title: Saw Blade Universal Case / Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created this for my 10" Hitachi Miter Saw blades, it fits very well and can be used for other size blades with scaling (skil saws, table saws, etc). Since this is made for 10" blade, all you would need to do to use it for a different size blade is scale it up or down by 10% per inch (so 7.25" blade would be scaled on Z and X axis 72.5%). I keep Y scaling at 100% since blade thickness doesn't change much and keeping it at 100% will make the two halves fit better

The outer piece has a window so you can see what kind of blade is inside without having to open it

I printed this on a 220x220mm platform using PLA at 190 degrees with 50 degree bed temp. I had problems with warping on buildtak type surface I normally use, so ended up fixing it by putting a strip of painters tape and printing on top of that, had no problems after that. I would recommend using use a 5mm or 8mm brim, no supports needed. Print it diagonally on the bed with the curved side pointing up and the flat side on the tape and brim. I did .3 layer and it worked fine. I printed the inner case without brim and edges came up slightly but it did not affect the fit at all, so if you don't feel like cleaning off the brim you can probably get away with printing inner shell without one, same may be true for outer, but I have not tried it

Eventually I'll add a customizer script so you can scale it before you download STL files, but this should be fairly simple with any slicer

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

100

Notes:

Place both pieces diagonally on bed with rounded end pointing up just like the first picture
Use a brim 5mm to 8mm, depending on how much room you have to work with
Use painter tape on top of your bed to make sure corners don't come up (or if you're into glue sticks or hair spray on glass, that might work too)
Use lowest possible temperature to prevent sagging or warping, 190 worked well for my PLA

from my brain to SketchUp 2017 to STL

17 failed outer shell designs (mainly due to some very interesting geometry in outer shell), 5 failed 8+ hour prints, many sleepless OCD driven allnighters, and here you have a pretty functional blade case. enjoy!

description.text:
OpenDungeonTiles: Door Standard Cell

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

Hello I have set up a Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/opendungeontiles

author: carternick01

description.text:
Anet A8 Double Heat Bed
At first i have to say thanks to SmallArtFly for making the Anet A8 frame in useable CAD files
All links are just samples

Warning!!!
not possible with 20A Power supply you will smoke it up
you need around 30A for this. Every Heat bed has 10A and start to use mosfet boards,
its not useful to send so much ampere over the Mainboard
Also i suggest you to solder the wires directly onto the heat bed, my plug smoked up.
as far as i know, they all do sooner or later. for second heat bed u have to remove the plug, and solder the wires directly onto the heat bed.
also you need to add additional lead, the 8mm steel is too weak and starts bouncing on print
sry im no instructions guy hope it will help what i wrote and is understandable ^^
feel free to ask, and maybe u get answered ;-)
Parts Needed
1x Heat Bed 220x220
(must be the same like the other one, cause u cant temperate them alone and have to use 2 beds parallel with just 1 PTC. But works pretty well they have nearly same temperature the difference here is around 2°c maybe with firmware changes it will be possible but still did not figured out how)
2m GT2 Belt
2x heat bed springs
(they are needed for the middle u need to arrange the print head distance there too
so you will have 6 points to level the bed after extending)
2x aloy or carbon plate 440x220x4 for heat bed carrier stability and as print bed
(i used Carbon around 170€ but u can print directly on it and its rly stable at 4mm)
2x 1m silver steel rod 8mm
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Silberstahl-8mm-Rund-1-2210-geschliffen-poliert-Länge-1000mm/172521494796?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649
2x 1m VA screw 8mm
2x I-Typ Profile 40x16x1000 With Drillholes through the whole lentgh of profile
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Aluminiumprofil-40x16S-I-Typ-Nut-8-Zuschnitt-50-1190mm-11-50-EUR-m-min-1-EUR-/282225635697?var=&hash=item41b5f57171:m:m_hMGu-VQluYoLY24kAYgxw
(needed for Stability if not used or something like this the heat bed starts bouncing prints get ruined for sure and the silver steel rod / bearings maybe gets damaged this profiles are rly stable)
16x bearing 3x6x2,5mm (for the sleds)
http://www.ebay.de/itm/10-x-Kugellager-Bearing-63-ZZ-3x6x2-5mm/151965772109?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649
M3 x20mm screws
for the i typ profile, make sure u screw some m3 screw through the plastic
before trying to make them in place, else they break, they are weak and just
for holding in place. if everything is ok threy dont get any forces on the I-typ
Profile just pressure from top cause of heat bed

8x M3 x 20mm screws
for the sled, to hold the bearings. Let them stand out some mm that the screws / sled
cant get over the linear bearings u will see that at assembling
the sleds dont get screwed at the heat bed carrier u can do it but i didnt, on this way the sleds cant leave place when pressure from bed is too low or not 100% parallel.
Also make sure u cleaned the bearing holes well from plastic the bearings must be able to turn very well, make some points with water proof pen on it is u had problems like me to see it turning. the screw holes should be drilled with 2.5mm then the screws make their own thread but u could use also a 3mm thread drill

Also i would suggest u to change the common linear bearings to plastic ones, maybe i just got bad bearings but they already destroied a silver steel rod and the new one has a scratch too
have them here but still not in use
http://www.ebay.de/itm/8x-DryLin-Igus-RJ4JP-01-08-Gleitlager-anstelle-LM8UU-RepRap-Mendel-Linearlager/272135737892?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649
there gets nothing rly screwed together it holds by its own thats why i cant help with the front holders, you need to create them by yourselft they depend on how long your i-typ profiles will be.
my silver steel rods are 77cm
my VA screws are 82 cm (yes i know i still didnt sawed them.... too lazy to disassamble )
my I-typ Profile is around 84 cm and 78 but as u can see in picture i messed it up^^ need a course in how to measure :-) and thats why you need to make the front holders by your own ;-) the front holder i posted is just a suggestion how to
to build the new heat bed carrier take the old one and mark the holes of it on the 440cm aloy or carbon 2 times that u have the holes for the linear bearings you just need the middle bearing holes and 4 bearings, but u need the holes at the side for endstop, be creative to make sure you reach it, i used a 2cm linearbearing spacer and the small block. u can compensate it in firmware also but if no endstop blöck is used heatbed carrier maybe crashes at the wall not good for your belt. Could be used to expend the heat bed a lil but there still should be heat at the edges of bed ^^
you need to place the 2cm blocks between linear bearing and heat bed carrier to make space for the i typ profile.
place the i typ profile spacers on 1/4 and 3/4 of travel way. place the i typ profile on the spacers and top /back acryl plates. the other one gets holded under the stepper. there should be now around 1mm space between bearing blocks and profile. put the sleds on it in the middle of carrier. if the sleds are too low, use some thick paper between sled and carrier (sand paper sand side on sled)
use the screws from the 8mm steel rod holders to add the additional i typ profile holders at the back u can use one of the spare part holders, this prevents the i typ proile from sliding backwards at the other side u take the ones i made to prevent the profile from sliding forward.

Made some spacers today for the profile to prevent them from bending and to keep them parallel, you should be able now to arrange the i typ profiles now easy between the linear beerings. be sure to put the sleds in before assembling the heat bed carrier, i dont think it will be possible later with spacers to get them into the middle

you should use some additional plate now were u screw the heat bed at i would suggest a material were you can print directly on it else use alloy, this is needed to have a plane surface with no edge coming up from one heat bed, i used 6x 30mm and 2x 12mm screws but i would suggest you to use 35 - 40mm makes it easier for the knurled nuts to get on

assemble the carrier like the old one only difference u will level the carrier not from top now, so u need some knurled nut, or cut a m3 thread into the alloy like it was made at the old carrier, not possible with carbon i think but i think its a bad solution cause u cant screw the heatbeds under the print surface tight with nuts. also u have now 6 points to level the Heat bed
Electric:
i use 3 mosfets for the reason that i use an ATX power supply with 60A double rail
2x 12v 30A so i can separate one heat bed to each rail, extruder on rail 1 mainboard on rail 2, and maybe later its possible to heat the bed separate and measure its temp

need to say it again!
solder the wires directly on bed, this plug is a real danger!!!! he can cause fire and burn down your house i saw it to the right time, plug got molten, some cm from the cables too, i think next print he had burned with luck just a shortcut
will post details on electric later if someone needs it
I am using the skynet firmware, works for Arduino 1,0 board and ramps 1.4 board very well
but since i have a diamond hotend im using a ramps 1.4 with cnc shield
Firmware:
You need to tell the machine that it has now the double Y axis length to do so change in
Configuration.h under "// Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)" for "#define Y_MAX_POS 220" and change it to 440 or how long your heat bed is.
feel to be inspired its all just a suggestion :-)

title: Wanhao i3 Plus Pi Cam mount

description.text:
Features:

  • Does not obstruct bed levelling knobs
  • Plenty of clearance when bed levelling springs are fully compressed.
  • Sturdy mounting system for your camera.
  • Fits the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus generic y-carriage plate including a cutout for the raised ridge near the edge of the plate.

Hardware:

  • 6 screws, each M4x10mm, with a flat head socket screw (aka, to fit into a countersunk hole).
  • Raspberry Pi Camera
  • If you wish to use another camera, see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1422072 for a more generic mount.

Assembly/Mounting:

  1. Power Off the printer and disconnect anything plugged into the USB port as there is a possibility of shorting the heated bed connection points!
  2. Screw the camera mount onto the plate with two (2) M4x10mm screws.
  3. Remove bed by removing the bed levelling knobs
  4. Test fit the mounting plate
  5. Remove the four screws from the bearing you wish to mount it on
  6. Using the M4x10mm screws, attach the plate/camera mount assembly.
  7. Replace the bed and levelling knobs
  8. Adjust the bed to its lowest position (springs fully compressed)
  9. Visually verify there are no shorted wires.
  10. Power up the printer.
  11. Level the bed.

Many thanks to user dumbcomputers and user OsmW for their skilled designs.

The camera holder (pi_cam_mount_v3.1.stl) is unmodified from OsmW's design as it's durn near perfect.

title: Viki LCD Tripod mount (US) and MakerGear M2 Side Bracket

description.text:
This Viki LCD housing has three tripod mount positions, left,middle and right. You'll need stainless steel hex nuts 1/4"-20 Threads. LCD housing can be mounted on any US standard tripod head. I'm using a motorcycle handlebar tripod mount with a custom made side bracket for MakerGear M2. You'll have to make your own handlebar for your printer. MakerGear M2 setup:
  • Please see the picture about wire position. Use Mounting Base to tie down the wires.
  • Side Bracket design didn't quite work the way I thought it would, so use a foam mounting tape to further secure the handlebar area. Newer M2 doesn't have the middle metal rod, but don't worry about it because foam tape will hold the handlebar in place securely.

I printed the LCD housing and Wire Plug with a 0.35 nozzle and hexagon pattern spacing of 2.5 mm. Side Bracket is for MakerGear M2 only. I used rectilinear support pattern of 2.5 mm. Assembly:
  • Insert hex nuts into the wells.
  • Insert Wire Plug to the LCD Housing from the inside (DO NOT GLUE them together).
  • Put LCD's two sets of wires through the Wire Plug and then connect the wires to LCD connectors.
  • Wrap the two sets of wires with electrical tape, so it has a snug-fit against the Wire Plug's opening. This prevents LCD connectors being pulled loose by its own wires.
  • Secure LCD to the LCD Housing with screws on four corners.

I think I rotated my top piece 90 degrees off of my slices position in my slicer, and I had to apply epoxy putty between the two parts to correct this,  so that would probably be something to keep in mind.

description.text:
The button on a really tall pedestal from the portal video game series, this fancy column will "stand" out in any room! I did not see any designs for a pedestal button, so I thought it would be fun to design it in CAD, and then print it out to see how it "stands here" in my room!
(Enough poorly thought puns ... well okay one more: "Press the button!" ...
... But actually listen to Wheatley, because with this design pushing the button does not actually do anything :D. If you want me to try design a spring design with the ability to integrate circuitry to do something cool, or have suggestions on how to accomplish that let me know.)

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.30

Infill:

.07-.10

Notes:

Printed all parts with PLA. Be forewarned: This project eats up a lot of plastic, and a lot of time (a lot of time if you are going to make the assembly as tall as mine).
Don't print with supports. Except for the button stl: use the "touching buildplate" option for that.
There doesn't need to be that much infill for this assembly, so I would go with at least 1.2mm top/bottom layer thickness. I also did 1mm shell thickness.

*One side note: if you change the orientation of the pedestal slices/top on the print bed in your slicer, I would advise against doing that because the physical print may appear crooked when you stack the pieces on each other (which you might notice in my pedestal). I think I rotated my top piece 90 degrees off of my slices position in my slicer, and I had to apply epoxy putty between the two parts to correct this, so that would probably be something to keep in mind.

Assembling

I bought skinny sticks (5.75 in x .25in) to hold the slices together with the slots in each part. The slots are 1in deep each, so you will need to measure and cut the sticks to fit them between the slices. (I also used the sticks when I made Adafruit's Hylian Shield, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824544)

In addition to sticks, you'll need super glue, putty, and a hair dryer possibly to make it easier to fit the parts of the assembly together (slice into foot, fit sticks in slots, button on pedestal top: all these were tight fits where I needed heat to help fit the parts together.

In Game

I studied in the game Portal 2 to manually draw each part of the assembly. I also decided with the height of mine, I wanted the pedestal to be tall enough for someone standing to be able to "push" the button. For that, I printed 5 slices with the top piece, which makes my pedestal end up standing 3 ft tall. Each slice is 6 inches tall, with 5 inches in diameter. The foot has been designed in a simple way (the four strips extending from the base are not included). If you don't want springs I included a version of the pedestal top that only has a spot for the button.
