author: Hiyo8111

title: Phone (nexus 5) stand with small passive amp and optional wireless charging

description.text:
This is a stand I made for my nexus 5 (size for my phone with a thin bumper case). One version is just a hollow stand, the other prints with multiple parts and is meant to become a wireless charger.
Don't look at the finish on the photo, hopefully your printer prints better than mine.

The low-down:
-it's a stand that fits a Nexus 5 with a thin bumper case, or any other phone that size.
-it'll send/reflect the sound of the speaker towards the front of the phone (without much volume change, but with an actual significant quality improvement), as long as the speaker is bottom left of the phone.
-it'll wirelessly charge your phone if you stick a wireless charger's working bits inside of it.
-there is a "cover" for the front bottom to hide most of the notification light, but that cover has a super small hole so that you can see it blink if you look straight at It (great at night)

I printed it in PLA, it used about 1.1 meter of it altogether at 15% infill (the part is hollow, so that helps), with 2 bottom, 2 side and 4 top layers. The sides of the hollow core are .8mm thick, so that 0.4mm extruder tips get to do 2 clean layers without the slicer fooling around with tiny gaps.

The details:
One of the STL files is hollow, and the part on which you lean the back of the phone is a glue-able cover so that you can glue the innards of a cheap wireless charger to it (see link below for the one I cannibalized), and the stand becomes a wireless charger. The rectangular hole in the back is to slide in a usb cord that plugs in the charger, which fits in the inside of the stand. If you do this, you just glue the cover to the rest of the stand (I used super glue, worked fine once I put enough of it all around the bevel on the stand and glue the cover to that).

The little v-shaped thing is soemthing you clip on the USB wire on the inside of the stand to prevent you from yanking the plug out of the charger if you pull the cord; you have to put it on the cord (inside the charger) as close to the back wall of the stand once you've established how much of the cord you need in the stand.

I also included a passive amplifier in the bottom part in all versions. It's not much of an amplifier since it's not very big, but I was surprised that on top of sending the sound forward of the phone, it actually does improve sound quality a lot (the nexus 5 has poor sound and seems to benefit from this quite a lot). Volume is most likely not all that different, but it's hard to say.

*the type of charger I used for parts: http://www.ebay.ca/itm/Qi-USB-Wireless-Charger-Charging-Pad-For-Galaxy-S6-Edge-Note-5-DP-/112257122127?var=&hash=item1a230bbf4f:m:mPyZtqPiE7ef-duRBue3wog

description.text:
I've been using the over size idler for 6 months printed solid out of ABS with no degradation from the Chlorine. The one I had was fine but my tires were getting thin and they would slip driving the rear wheel. It would probably be too tight for new tires but the files are provided so you could make the outer diameter the correct size.

The bag quick release works well.

I printed the full size wheel but have never tried it. Looks like it would work fine. You need
a printer that prints the correct size or the bearings of course won't fit. The files are included and it would be easy to open them in fusion and move the bearing holes in or out a hair. They need to be solid so they have less tendency to float.

I printed a tire out of Ninajaflex and it worked but it turned color in just a few days and I didn't print it solid so it tended to float too much. One of these days I'm going to make a new wheel design using 608 ceramic bearings.

Fusion360 files shared below.

description.text:
Kalorik Contempo Salt and Pepper Grinder Set that I got from Amazon (ASIN B019C4FJXC) is nice, but a bit of a pain to carry around because of its large size and the fact that there are two.
This holder solves the problem by making it easier to carry.
It was intentionally made short to fit my small cabinet, but the wide handle makes it easier to grab than it looks.

Infill of 40% or more may be needed for strength, depending on the filament used.
Both the holder and the accent ring can be printed together for a dual-extruder printer, but the color may bleed. The ring is hard to print by itself without a brim (or lots of AquaNet), though, because of small bed surface contact.

Made this to put in silica gel beads after the ones I bought ended up all over.

Print it standing up as set up in the STL file so you don't need supports or minimal bridging. might look a little rough because it's very small columns and printers don't like that.

Print it (with a 0.4mm nozzle) 100% infill, 2 bottom, 2 sides and 2 top layers. The object is made with 0.8mm walls so that fits perfect with 2 side layers, wich means you don't have an gaps between the layers.

It probably can be printed at 200% without the beads passing through the slits. It IS a little on the small side of things.

Might need to sand the slip-in cap to fit it in, the tolerances are rather tight.

comments.text: As mentioned in the description the Top piece that slips inside the tall tower is impossible to put in and needs to be sanded down. It would be helpful if the print was saved as 2 seperate pieces. I was able to edit it in Meshmixer and delete one part and print the other separately but it was a pain. The print is nice at around 220% but the top piece should probably be set at around 200-210% or so. It would be nice if the box was a bit wider since it is really small. you need to be careful about it falling over which i had happen a few times due to its height and being so skinny and my bed adhesion ended up giving out. so you may want to use a brim or raft if your having issues as well. otherwise great print.

author: Loganator100

description.text: This is a simple adapter I made to fit the tiny cup holders that came with my new couch. The new couch had 89mm cup holders and this ring adapter is a snug press fit into them and can now hold upto a 105mm mug and also holds cups up to 76mm in the center hole.

** UPDATE ***
I realized the Extruder-07.stl is newer but didn't have the clips.
Use Extruder-06.stl for the clips. The clips should be in the correct locations.

Also, do not print with supports. Depending on the printer, I assume a Makerbot that uses the SmartExtruder, will be able to print the bridges just fine.
** End Update ***

I own two original SmartExtruders and one SmartExtruder+. I've figured out the SmartExtruder+ is great because and only because it's held on by screws instead of clips. They are about the same as far as performance goes, but it's nice to have more extruders dedicate for different nozzle diameters.

Anyway, anyone who owns one of these 5th Gens or had owned one would understand the frustrations of the clip-on extruder covers. Mine are holding on to dear life by my extruder holder or painters' tape, since it's readily available.

The part is self explanatory so there are little words to say about this part, other than I've put in about 2 weeks of work on this, but it's not quite right yet. Measurements were taken and modeled with and without the back-cover for assembly for accuracy, before and after printing. Printed parts were checked under a microscope then the model was adjusted accordingly. Well, I hadn't finished it yet, but it's roughly 90% accurate.

Other work got in the way and I hadn't worked on this for a couple months and decided to release this to all of you. If it works for you, GREAT! If it doesn't, I hope someone can finish it, make improvements and share it.

It's best to print this at 0.3mm resolution and print it solid. 0.2mm is better but that's a lot of time spent for an incomplete part that may or may not work. There aren't any features there that require 0.2mm resolution. 0.4mm prints faster but I feel it's not fine enough for this application.

I've printed only PLA but it hasn't quite fit JUST right so I have no idea what will happen at the hot-end.

Enjoy.

title: Kelty Discovery sun shade joint connectors

description.text:
I bought a Kelty Discovery sun shade from REI. While camping in Oregon for the eclipse, we had a big gust of wind hit us and one of the plastic connectors broke. I called Kelty and they said they don't have parts for this model! It's a decent shade for the money, so rather than return it I decided to see if I could figure out how to make my own connectors. I use FreeCad - the challenge was getting the angles right, but once I understood how to create a small "helper" object with three surfaces at the needed angles, the rest was pretty easy.

I think the connectors I printed are actually stronger than the original - I made them a little thicker and with much beefier reinforcement angles. They do weigh about 30% or so more...

There are 3 different connectors. A & B are the corners, print two of each. C is the center connector, you'll need two of these as well. All of them have labels on them showing "A", "B", or "C", and the angles 90 and 100 degrees as appropriate.

Update 09/04/17: Added version 5 - slightly thicker tube wall, bottom trimmed flat so they print "as is" without the small bulge on the bottom.

I hope this helps someone else!
As usual (for me), designed in FreeCad and source files are included.

Update 10/25/17: Added version 7 - tubes are now 8 sided instead of round for easier printing, and I fixed the angle on one of the pieces.

If you print these in PLA, be sure to use a higher temperature than normal to get added strength. When I printed them in PLA at the usual (220C) they weren't strong enough and separated at the print layers. Printed at 270 in PLA they are much stronger, although in the end I decided to print them using PETG...

Example of one way to do complex angles in FreeCAD

Designed in FreeCAD - there is a small rectangular post in the center that establishes the surfaces for the three tubes. Two of the tubes are always at 90 degrees, but for the corners the third tube is at 100 degrees and pointed out a bit (10 degrees?) to make the shelter more stable.

remixed_from.title: Simple Duct for Tactical X Carriage

description.text:
This is a Fang Tactical X Carriage Fan duct, meant to work with the excellent design of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2087128/#files

While not truly a remix, as it was drawn from scratch, I based it to work with the designs attributed in the Remix section.

This should work on an original E3D V6, a clone, Cyclops, or Chimera (I haven't tested the Chimera yet). If you find any issues with it, please let me know. It took 4 iterations to get it to this stage.

When the design stabilizes a bit, I will post the F3D file for it as well.

Sorry for my rough "As Built" picture, but I wanted to post this, and haven't had the time to make it prettier.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or better

Infill:

n/a

Notes:

I recommend printing this with the square portion down (as illustrated in the STL file), using a wide brim of about 15mm. If your printer can bridge at all decently, it does not require any supports. The overhangs at the top will really push your printers limits though. Think of this as a torture test.

To scale it properly, once imported, do a uniform scale to 10%. (This is due to my Fusion 360 having the wrong units set).

From there, it is critical that you measure the distance you need the fang to be, as each extruder is slightly different. To make that adjustment you need to measure the distance from the bottom of your carriage to where you want the bottom of the fang to be. Then add 11.175mm for the part that goes into the carriage, and this is your total desired height.

Then scale in your slicer, only along the Z axis to this new number. Mine was about 66mm in total. That way, the height is adjusted, and the relative size of the connector that goes into the carriage remains the correct dimensions.

comments.text: Problem right away importing into Simplify3D. The default dimensions are X 485.46 by Y 375.64 by Z 677.66
comments.author: ironval

comments.text:
Sorry, Fusion 360 sometimes does weird things, because STLs don't have a unit of measurement in them.
When I import into the slicer, I have to scale to 10%.
From there, it is critical that you measure the distance you need the fang to be, as each extruder is slightly different.
To make that adjustment you need to measure the distance from the bottom of your carriage to where you want the bottom of the fang to be. Then add 11.175mm for the part that goes into the carriage, and this is your total desired height.
Then scale in your slicer, only along the Z axis to this new number. Mine was about 66mm in total.

This a T-bar style jewelry display for necklaces. It can be used at home or to display necklaces that are for sale.

The bar is two inches in diameter, eight inches wide and the top of the bar is twelve inches above the base. The base is six inches by three and a half inches.

--- Printing ---
1) Print the base upside down. No supports necessary.
2) Print the extension standing up with the necked down portion at the top. Print with 100% infill. No supports necessary.
3) Print the T-bar on the flat backside. Suggest printing with 10% infill. Supports are necessary only where it necks down to fit into the extension during assembly.

--- Assembly ---
1) The parts have been designed with lead-in chamfers to ease alignment during assembly.
2) This has been designed with a tight slip fit. It should slide together easily and not come apart without force. Glue is unnecessary but can be used to make the assembly permanent.
3) Once the small amount of support has been removed from the T-bar it will slide into the extension piece with minimal support.
4) The above two pieces slide into the base.

description.text:
After making the vibration damper: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1707045
I wasn't happy with the wobbling of the Z-axis even after turning the acceleration way down.

These are designed specifically for my setup: using the full size vibration dampers and keeping the felt feet included with the MK2S on. I've had no issues using the vibration dampers with the felt feet on the printer.
If you don't have the felt feet on the printer these stabilizers are definitely too tall.

They're purposely slightly short to allow for adding a strip of bicycle tube in the stabilizer track. After adding tube to the track they have a slight amount of friction against the bottom of the Z-axis frame but the frame isn't really supported by the stabilizer. The weight of the printer is still supported by the feet.

remixed_from.author: dumbcomputers
remixed_from.title: Wanhao i3 Adjustable Tension Extruder Lever

title: Prusa I3 Migbot (and varients) adjustable tension extruder arm

description.text:
The original adjustable tension extruder lever by dumbcomputers was unfortunately a tad off for some cheaper Chinese kit printers. As such, I modified the file to put the bearing directly below the top joint at a 90 degree angle instead of slightly offset like it was in the original model. This allows the lever to be used for a wider variety of printers, including my prusa i3 migbot, that have larger springs and normally stick out further above the extruder assembly.

This print does require a bit of post processing if using the same setup and screws that I did. You can see that the bearing screw is slightly larger than the hole of the print, but a file, knife, or other such object should be able to open it up enough.

Additionally, the files could use a bit of fine tuning. As you can see in the second picture, the side wall of the lever came off when attaching the cover, but it still works fine without it. Since this design doesn't completely cover the bearing you can also just glue the two parts together if you so desire.

title: A4 Pen Plotter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Remixed to add cover and allow for Wantai Motor 42BYGHW811 (available off of ebay for around $10.00 Canadian, shipping extra. Will also work with OpenBuilds nema 17 motor (at time of creation of this entry).

Remixes

Four pieces from JuanGg's original have been modified. This allows for a nema 17 stepper motor with up to a 48 mm body length to be used instead of being limited to a stepper motor with a maximum 31 mm body length. I had four already. I also modified the "switch support plate."

Four cover pieces have been added. The front and rear cover plate could be replaced with 2 mm thick acrylic plate.

Possible modification I can think of.

The stepper motors are on opposite ends of this plotter. I think it could be modified to put the x axis motor on the same end as the y axis motor. If the end stop switch is also moved, there would not be be any cables running from the left end of the plotter to the right end of the plotter. This would also allow easier upgrading from one paper width to another.

It may be possible to add a rotary cutter to the x axis that could be enabled independent of the pen allowing for continuous roll paper to be automatically cut after printing. Paper roll handling is likely not going to be trivial.

The pen could be replaced with a readily available injet print head allowing for an "opensource" printer to be created.

The media handling could be modified to allow using standard single or double sided PCB blanks to be used. For this, the pen could be replaced with either a "sharpie(tm)" to trace out etch resist on the board, or perhaps an appropriately coloured laser for photosensitive boards to be used. In the later case, this would allow for photosensitive solder mask and "silk screen" materials to also be used.

Simple wall mount for any cell phone. Opening on the bottom for charging cable. Holes are to save on filament as this is not load bearing. Will not work as a desktop mount. Just to play around I added "S7" inside the tray but should work with most cell phones up to 5.5 inches in height. The opening on the bottom is not made to hold the charging cable in place. Just there to let the phone rest level. (Too lazy to adjust the STL, picture shows correct orientation)

Hope you dig it!
